Question: While driving, a Class G1 learner must be supervised by an accompanying driver. The blood-alcohol level of the accompanying driver must be less than
If you are found guilty of backing on a highway or driving too slowly, ____ demerit points will be added to your driving record.
Do NOT park anywhere that you don't have a clear view for at least _____ metres in both directions.

If you are convicted for the first time of driving while your licence is suspended, you will get an additional six-month suspension, and you will also face which of the following additional penalties?
Option_A: Either Jail time or a fine or both
Option_B: Six months in jail
Option_C: Neither Jailtime nor a fine
Option_D: A fine of between $1,000 and $5,000

Question: If you are convicted of following too closely (tailgating), ____ demerit points will be added to your driving record.
If you are found guilty of carrying a child passenger who is not properly secured, ____ demerit points will be added to your driving record.
A G2 driver age 19 or younger who has 6 months or less of driving experience may carry ____ unrelated passenger(s) age 19 or younger between midnight and 5:00 a.m.
If you are found guilty of going the wrong way on a one-way road, ____ demerit points will be added to your driving record.
Under Ontario's Move Over law, you are required to
Option_A: change lanes if safe when passing a stopped emergency vehicle with its lights flashing.
Option_B: move into the rightmost lane if you are driving slower than other traffic.
Option_C: pull over if an emergency vehicle is following you with its lights flashing.
Option_D: do none of the above.

Question: A G2 driver age 19 or younger who has more than 6 months of driving experience may carry ____ unrelated passenger(s) age 19 or younger between midnight and 5:00 a.m.
You will receive _____ the first time you are convicted of a Criminal Code offence.
Option_A: a lifetime ban from driving
Option_B: a one-month licence suspension
Option_C: a one-year licence suspension
Option_D: a two-year licence suspension

Question: You may NOT park within _______ of an intersection that is NOT controlled by traffic lights.
Option_A: 15 metres
Option_B: 5 metres
Option_C: 7 metres
Option_D: 9 metres

Question: When passing a cyclist, you must leave at least ____ of space between your vehicle and the cyclist.
Option_A: 2 metres
Option_B: 0.5 metre
Option_C: 1.5 metres
Option_D: 1 metre

Question: A G1 or G2 driver who is caught drinking and driving will face which of the following penalties?
Option_A: A 30-day licence suspension if convicted
Option_B: An immediate 3-day licence suspension
Option_C: A fine of up to $500 if convicted
Option_D: All of the above

Question: While driving on a two-way street, you hear the siren of an approaching emergency vehicle. What does the law require you to do?
Option_A: Signal the driver to pass.
Option_B: Speed up and get out of the way.
Option_C: Continue at the same speed.
Option_D: Pull to the right as far as possible and stop.

Question: If a fully licensed driver accumulates 15 or more demerit points on his or her record, the driver's licence will be suspended for
Option_A: 90 days.
Option_B: 30 days.
Option_C: 14 days.
Option_D: 60 days.

Question: If you are approaching an intersection at which the traffic lights are not working, you should
Option_A: yield to the traffic to your right.
Option_B: slow down and proceed with caution.
Option_C: stop until no other vehicles are approaching and then go.
Option_D: treat it as if there were all-way stop signs.

Question: If one of your tires suddenly blows out while you're driving, what should you do?
Option_A: Bring the vehicle to a stop off the road.
Option_B: Take your foot off the gas pedal.
Option_C: Concentrate on steering.
Option_D: Do all of the above.

Question: When approaching a Merging Traffic sign, you should
Option_A: adjust your speed and position.
Option_B: honk your horn.
Option_C: stop your vehicle before proceeding.
Option_D: let the cars behind you go first.

Question: If the signal light changes from green to yellow (amber) as you approach an intersection, what should you do?
Option_A: Speed up to get past the yellow light before it turns red.
Option_B: Continue through the intersection without slowing or stopping.
Option_C: Stop. If a stop cannot be made safely, proceed with caution.
Option_D: Sound your horn to warn pedestrians and other drivers that you do not intend to stop.

Question: In Ontario, when driving at night, you must dim your headlights
Option_A: whenever you are within 60 metres of an oncoming vehicle or within 150 metres of a vehicle you are following.
Option_B: whenever you are within 400 metres of another vehicle.
Option_C: whenever you are within 150 metres of another vehicle.
Option_D: whenever you are within 150 metres of an oncoming vehicle or within 60 metres of a vehicle you are following.

Question: Under what circumstances may a driver's licence be cancelled?
Option_A: For possession of an altered driver's licence
Option_B: For failure to attend a driver re-examination
Option_C: For failure to satisfactorily complete a driver re-examination
Option_D: Any of the above circumstances

Question: At an intersection, the traffic light is red, but a police officer motions you to go through. What should you do?
Option_A: Wait for the light to turn green.
Option_B: Go through.
Option_C: Stop and make sure that the police officer really wants you to go through.
Option_D: Tell the police officer that the light is red.

Question: A flashing green light at an intersection where left and right turns are permitted means
Option_A: you may turn right.
Option_B: you may turn left.
Option_C: you may go straight.
Option_D: all of the above.

Question: If you are convicted of fleeing a police officer who signaled you to pull over, your licence will be suspended for
Option_A: 4 years.
Option_B: 5 years.
Option_C: 2 years.
Option_D: 3 years.

Question: While driving, you receive a call on your hand-held cell phone. There are no passengers who can take the call for you. What should you do?
Option_A: Answer the phone and promise to call the person back later.
Option_B: Answer the phone only if you've been expecting an important call.
Option_C: Pull over and park before using your cell phone.
Option_D: Text back the caller to let him know that you're driving.

Question: If you are involved in an accident in which someone is injured, you must
Option_A: report the accident to the police within 48 hours.
Option_B: report the accident to the Ministry of Transportation within 48 hours.
Option_C: report the accident to the police immediately.
Option_D: report the accident to the Ministry of Transportation immediately.

Question: If you are convicted of careless driving, you will receive six demerit points and you may face
Option_A: a jail sentence of up to six months.
Option_B: licence suspension for up to two years.
Option_C: a fine of up to $2,000.
Option_D: all of the above.

Question: If you change your name or address, you must notify the Ministry of Transportation within
Option_A: 6 days.
Option_B: 45 days.
Option_C: 14 days.
Option_D: 30 days.

Question: If two vehicles arrive at an uncontrolled intersection at approximately the same time, the right-of-way should be given to:
Option_A: The vehicle approaching from the left
Option_B: The one moving faster
Option_C: The vehicle approaching from the right
Option_D: Neither one

Question: When entering a highway, what must drivers do?
Option_A: Stop on the acceleration lane, wait for an opening, and then enter the freeway rapidly.
Option_B: Signal, increase speed, and merge smoothly with traffic
Option_C: Slow down, then enter the freeway at a sharp angle
Option_D: Drive slowly and be prepared to stop for freeway traffic

Question: When parked facing uphill with a curb:
Option_A: Turn the steering wheel to the right
Option_B: Turn the steering wheel to the left
Option_C: The direction of the wheels doesn’t matter as long as the parking brake is set
Option_D: The front wheels must be parallel to the curb

Question: A person whose driver licence is under suspension, may
Option_A: operate a motor vehicle in the case of an extreme emergency
Option_B: operate a motor vehicle when accompanied by a licensed driver
Option_C: not operate a motor vehicle under any circumstance
Option_D: operate a motor vehicle to and from work

Question: When it is safe to do so, passing other vehicles on the right side
Option_A: Is permitted providing it is possible to do so by driving on the shoulder of the road
Option_B: Is not permitted under any circumstance
Option_C: Is permitted at any time on any street or highway
Option_D: Is permitted when the street or highway has two or more lanes for traffic in the direction the vehicle is traveling.

Question: In what lane must drivers be before making a left turn from a one-way street?
Option_A: In the lane closest to the center line of the roadway
Option_B: The lane does not matter provided the driver signals
Option_C: In the lane closest to the left-hand side of the roadway
Option_D: In the lane closest to the right-hand side of the roadway

Question: When a streetcar is stopped to take on or discharge passengers where there is no safety zone, what does the law require drivers to do before passing the streetcar?
Option_A: Stop at least two metres behind the rear doors where passengers are getting on or off
Option_B: Pass on the left side when the way is clear
Option_C: Sound horn and pass with caution
Option_D: Stop behind the rear of the streetcar, then proceed with caution

Question: A white arrow painted on a lane means….?
Option_A: You may move only in the direction of the arrow
Option_B: Stop before the arrow and yield to pedestrians
Option_C: Move to the far left or far right lane as soon as the way is clear
Option_D: It shows where you must stop

Question: If an emergency vehicle with lights on and sirens sounding is travelling on a street that allows for two-way traffic, what does the law require drivers to do?
Option_A: Pull to the right as far as possible and stop
Option_B: Continue at the same speed
Option_C: Speed up and get out of the way
Option_D: Signal the driver to pass

Question: If a driver is caught driving with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) from —————-, the police can immediately suspend the driver’s license up to three days for a first occurrence.
When may drivers pass on the right shoulder?
Option_A: Whenever it can be done safely
Option_B: Never
Option_C: At any time a vehicle is turning left, even if the right shoulder is unpaved
Option_D: Only when passing a vehicle turning left and only if the right shoulder is paved

Question: How many meters in both directions must drivers be able to see in order to make a legal U-turn?
Option_A: 150 metres
Option_B: 250 metres
Option_C: 100 metres
Option_D: 50 metres

Question: What lane of traffic should drivers use when they intend to make a right-hand turn?
Option_A: The lane closest to the right side of the road
Option_B: The lane approaching from the left
Option_C: The lane closest to the center line of the road
Option_D: The lane closest to the left side of the road

Question: When driving with headlights on, in what situations are drivers required to use low beam headlights?
Option_A: within 50 metres of an oncoming vehicle
Option_B: within 300 metres of an oncoming vehicle
Option_C: within 150 metres of an oncoming vehicle
Option_D: within 30 metres of an oncoming vehicle

Question: Why must a vehicle undergo emission testing?
Option_A: Because the vehicle registration needs to be renewed
Option_B: Because the vehicle is past a certain age
Option_C: All answers are correct
Option_D: Because the vehicle may be grossly polluting the environment

Question: If your phone rings while driving:
Option_A: All answers are correct
Option_B: Let it go to voice mail
Option_C: Have a passenger take the call
Option_D: Pull over and park to use your cell phone

Question: When a police officer signals a driver to pull the vehicle over:
Option_A: The driver must slow down, pull over as far to the right as safely possible and come to a complete stop
Option_B: The driver must slow down, pull over as far to the left as safely possible and come to a complete stop
Option_C: The driver must slow down and stop the vehicle in the driving lane it has been using
Option_D: The driver must continue driving until the nearest parking lot, signal, pull into the parking lot, and stop

Question: When does the law require lights on vehicles to be turned on?
Option_A: Between sunset and sunrise
Option_B: Between sunset and sunrise as well as any other time visibility is not clear for a distance of 150m
Option_C: Between half an hour before sunset to half an hour after sunrise and at any other time visibility is not clear for a distance of 150m
Option_D: No specified time

Question: When arriving at an intersection which has no stop line, crosswalk or sidewalk, where must drivers stop?
Option_A: Right beside the stop sign
Option_B: Right before the stop sign
Option_C: A little into the intersection
Option_D: At the edge of the intersection

Question: A flashing red beacon above an intersection means:
Option_A: Drivers must come to a complete stop and move through the intersection only when it is safe to do so
Option_B: Signal light is out of order, proceed with caution
Option_C: Slow down and drive with increased caution
Option_D: Slow down and if necessary yield right-of-way to vehicles approaching from the left or right

Question: High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes on provincial highways are reserved for vehicles with how many occupants?
Option_A: 3 or more people
Option_B: 4 or more people
Option_C: Any vehicle that is travelling above the posted speed limit
Option_D: At least two people
